review.title: Modeling the Sequence of Brain Volumes by Local Mesh Models for Brain Decoding
review.abstract: We represent the sequence of fMRI (Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging) brain volumes recorded during a cognitive stimulus by a graph which consists of a set of local meshes. The corresponding cognitive process, encoded in the brain, is then represented by these meshes each of which is estimated assuming a linear relationship among the voxel time series in a predefined locality. First, we define the concept of locality in two neighborhood systems, namely, the spatial and functional neighborhoods. Then, we construct spatially and functionally local meshes around each voxel, called seed voxel, by connecting it either to its spatial or functional p-nearest neighbors. The mesh formed around a voxel is a directed sub-graph with a star topology, where the direction of the edges is taken towards the seed voxel at the center of the mesh. We represent the time series recorded at each seed voxel in terms of linear combination of the time series of its p-nearest neighbors in the mesh. The relationships between a seed voxel and its neighbors are represented by the edge weights of each mesh, and are estimated by solving a linear regression equation. The estimated mesh edge weights lead to a better representation of information in the brain for encoding and decoding of the cognitive tasks. We test our model on a visual object recognition and emotional memory retrieval experiments using Support Vector Machines that are trained using the mesh edge weights as features. In the experimental analysis, we observe that the edge weights of the spatial and functional meshes perform better than the state-of-the-art brain decoding models.

sections.heading: II. NEUROIMAGING DATA COLLECTION
sections.text: A. Visual Recognition ExperimentIn this experiment, fMRI measurements were recorded while participants completed a one-time repetition task, which consisted of grayscale images of two categories, birds and flowers. Each stimulus was presented for 4 seconds, followed by an 8-second rest period.

sections.heading: B. Emotional Memory Retrieval Experiment
sections.text: In this experiment, the stimuli consisted of two neutral (kitchen utensils and furniture) and two emotional (fear and disgust) image categories. Each study began with a 12-second fixation phase, followed by a 6-second coding phase. In the coding phase, participants received 5 images of the same category, each lasting 1200 seconds on the screen. Following the fifth image, a 12-second delay phase was presented, in which participants completed three mathematical tasks consisting of the addition or subtraction of two randomly selected two-digit numbers. After the third math task, a 2-second repetition phase began, in which participants were presented with a test image from the same category and indicated whether the image was a member of the current study list or not. For a similar experiment setup, we refer to [24]. For classification, we used measurements obtained during the coding or retrieval phase as test data or training data.

sections.heading: III. PRE-PROCESSING OF ANALYSIS OF NEUROIMAGING DATA
sections.text: SPM8 was used for pre-processing and data analysis1. Pre-processing of the images consisted of (a) correcting the section capture timing between sections, (b) adjusting the images to the first volume in each fMRI run to correct head movement, (c) normalizing functional and anatomical images to a standard template provided by SPM2, and (d) smoothing images with a 6 mm wide, semi-maximum isotropic Gaussian nucleus. Finally, we extract 116 regions of automated anatomical labeling (AAL) [25] using Marsbar [26]. For the visual object recognition experiment, active voxels implemented in the SPM were identified, and the occipital lobe was selected as our region of interest (ROI).

sections.heading: IV. SPATIAL AND FUNCTIONAL LOCAL MESHES
sections.text: The local network model proposed in this study is constructed from a collection of voxels within a neighborhood of each voxel. To this end, we first create a formal definition of locality, which is accomplished by defining spatial and functional neighborhood systems. Then, we define two types of local networks, namely spatial and functional networks. In the following subsections, we present the formal definition of neighborhood systems and local networks.

sections.heading: V. CLASSIFICATION OF COGNITIVE STATES FOR BRAIN DECODING
sections.text: To this end, we use machine learning methods in which the coding of a cognitive state is represented by the training phase and the decoding state corresponds to the recognition phase of a classification algorithm. Then, the main question is how well a cognitive state can be represented by the network? The answer to this question can be observed in part from the performance of the classification process. Remember that for each cognitive stimulus si with a label c we record a sequence of brain volumes, with the number of brain volumes D in this sequence depending on the duration of the stimulus. This sequence of brain volumes is considered a sample with a label c, in the training set. To represent a cognitive state corresponding to a stimulus si with the mesh ensembles, we estimate the edge weights of all local meshes extracted from the corresponding sequence of brain volumes.

sections.heading: VI. BRAIN DECODING EXPERIMENTS PERFORMED ON THE FMRI DATASETS
sections.text: In order to verify the validity of the proposed network models, we conduct two groups of experiments: In the first group, we train and test an SVM classifier (Support Vector Machine) using the marked fMRI data recorded using the experimental setups described in Section II. In this group of experiments, we investigate the performance of the models to represent brain coding and decoding tasks. In the second group, we analyze the validity of the local networks by examining the similarities between the voxel time series in each network and the distribution of the error of the proposed linear regression model.

sections.heading: VII. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this study, we propose a method that maps a sequence of brain volumes recorded during a cognitive stimulus into a brain diagram that consists of a series of local networks. The proposed model, called the "ensemble of local networks," defines two types of local networks around each voxel, namely spatially local network (SLM) and functionally local network (FLM). While SLM models the relationship between voxel-BOLD responses in a spatial neighborhood system, FLM models the relationship between voxel-BOLD responses in functional neighborhood, which is defined by Pearson correlation. We have observed that we look at the total BOLD responses recorded during a cognitive stimulus for the application of spatial and functional relationships between voxels, so that we can model the discriminatory information in fMRI data. If we represent the brain, we encode FLM characteristics, and we decipher learning algorithms to function better (i.e. the VMR support).
